Nature: Power and Politics
As we linger over the lengthy press coverage of our decaying environment, the Chesapeake nuclear power plant
controversy provides another jarring example of man's neglect of his surroundings.
The dispute centers around radiation and "heat pollution" problems of the proposed nuclear plant. The steam
produced by the heat from nuclear fuel would be cooled
indirectly by water drawn from the Chesapeake Bay. When
this water is returned to the Bay, it would be 10 degrees
warmer and contain small amounts of tritium, a radioactive
form of hydrogen.
Many ecologists have argued that Federal regulations for
radioactive waste are too lax, but such objections were ruled irrelevant at the March 2 power plant hearing. Only
present criteria, set by the Atomic Energy Commission,
were considered for the water use permit for the Baltimore
Gas and Electric Company; the AEC had ruled that water
could enter ten degrees warmer from the nuclear plant.
The Federal Water Pollution Control Agency, however,
has stated that water temperature should not be raised
over 4 degrees. Meanwhile, consultants hired to study the
effect of a water change on marine life have not yet determined the temperature range for a "substantial" number of
species in the Bay.
Although the decision has not been formally reached, it
is clear that the BG and E will be permitted to use Bay
water for their nuclear plant despite the confusion over its
advisability. Before the hearings, a task force reported,
"Excavation at the Calvert Cliffs site began before the first
public hearing by the AEC, and construction permits were
issued although no approval has yet been obtained from
.the Department of Water Resources for permission to use
Chesapeake Bay water to cool the condensers."
The Nixon Administration has proposed an Environmental .Control Organization to try to involve students in
, the _preservation of /bur natuial environment, along the

would be to make an inventory of all publicly-owned land
and suggest changes in the use of our resources. Their work

By CHRISTOPHER OLANDER
It is at the periphery of social protest, is
funny yet almost tragic; its adherents take it all
quite seriously and spectators, somewhat as in a
circus, look on in a stupified manner. Its rumblings can probably be traced back to the last
century and its bible is a pernicious little book
by Betty Friedan. It is the Women's Liberation
Movement.
The cult of feminism, not to be confused with
Women's Lib, is founded on the absolutely true
hypothesis that women have been denied, by law
and rocial convention, the typical outlets for
success enjoyed by men. That is, they are discriminated against. There are many true believers in the feminist ranks and sentiment grows
yearly. The pill, the nursery school and the many
household beneficiaries of technology have freed
the American woman from her traditional roles
of incubator, mother and household maid and, with
increased educational opportunities and with the
aid of the media, she has found herself fearless,
truculent and free in the midst of a society in
which men pre-dominate.
These, however, are not the women of the Women's Lib movement. The modern American
woman, described above, may sympathize with
her extreme exual cohorts, but she is too steeped in the traditional values of society to go out
and openly antagonize people. Moreover, the
typical American woman is increasingly healthy
sexually, unhypocritical and, put simply, still
likes the company of men.

Fully Developed
Mlle. de Beauvior, author of The Second Sex,
speaks well for the feminist movement and
writes in a realistic vein about the relationship
between the sexes: "Full development of(female
eroticism) requires that--in love, affection, sensuality-- woman succeed in overcoming her passivity and in establishing a relation of reciprocity with her partner." Here we have an ax that
has needed grinding for a long time. Women have
always, until quite recently, had to suppress natural desire and behavior in order to conform to
a social or ethical norm. The sexually repressed
Victorian woman of Freud's day showed the horror
of what happens when sexual drives are blocked
by convention. In fact, as one writer has pointed
out, only Queens and prostitutes have enjoyed the
freedom necessary to indulge in the less saintly
activities.
Women's Lib insists that women must totally
liberate themselves from sexual "slavery." Most

Reviewing Records, Eren If They Aren't
By ELLIOT KRIEGER
There's something about the Firesign
'Theatre that makes me want to trust
them. It's partly that their fi.rst record
("Waiting for the Electrician, or Someone Like Him") was so brilliant. It's
Partly that I feel that they're working
On a form of dramatic communication
both very old and very new--and maybe
very important.
The Firesign Theatre makes records,
but, formally, they are kissing cousins
with the radio drama-- a dramatic event
created in the studio rather than on the
stage. True, radio drama imposes some
drasitc (and obvious) limitations on the
'resources of tne drama. But radio drama has its own intrinsic advantages. For
one thing, the audience, participating with
only one sense, expects much less of a
dramatic illusion and is therefore more
willing to accept rapid leaps in time,
Space and sensibility -- a particularly
' appropriate advantage for a contemporary dramatic medium.
Another thing -- when made in a recording studio, radio drama can have
a near infinite number of characters,
events and effect; and a near minimum
of mistakes. Also, audial performance
before a private audience can create
some very intriguing psychologie situations—creation of paranoic reaction,
second person direct address, inclusion
of the audience in the sound pattern.
And then, considering the marketability
and accessibility of records, I'm surprised (and sorry) that radio drama
has not yet become a trend.

Unstageable
As to their first record-- if you haven't
heard it, you should have. I would call it
a syntactic and a vocal drama. It relies
heavily on homonym and malaprop and on

an astonishing diversity of accent and
inflection. "Electrician" could not be
staged, not even in the mind (as one
tends to "stage" written narratives such
as novels). I have often wondered whether it could be filmed, and have decided
that although it probably could, it should
not be.
Part of the brilliance of "Electrician" is its fluidity-- almost as soon
as one can identify locale, one is shuffled along, without transition, to a new
place. Any addition of visual imagery
would add either new clues or new confusion. Neither are needed-- the record's timing is perfect. "Electrician" is one of those very rare art works
in which the form is a totally appropriate extension of the content.
What worried me was the content. The
record was an apocalyptic work-- selfconsciously so. Now when a group's
first work is an apocalypse, what happens
next? I would say that they either regress, repeat, or become immortal. The
Firesign Theatre may have done all
three.

Uncanny Verbal Dexterity
Their second record is called "How
Can You Be in Two Places At Once,
When You're Not Anywhere At All"
(Columbia, CS-9884). The cover of the
record bears the slogan "All Hail Marx
and Lennon"— beneath pictures of Grouch° and John. This gives you an idea of
what to watch out for in "How Can..."-bad puns. Side one of this record contains a great deal of vaudeville-like humor; and to my mind, for a group with
the talents of the Firesign Theatre,
that's just fodder.

Yet, their verbal dexterity, their uncanny ability at the double-talk/doubletake and the non sequitor, so apparent

in "Electrician", seems to have reached new levels of pointed insanity in
"How Can...": the 'here' is told to go
to the People, "who wouldn't say no to
yesterday, or yes instead of knowing it
A sign on the highway reads
all!"
"Merging Buses Ahead." A motorist
shouts, "Get a hair-lip!" Also, the Firesign Theatre has even improved its
ability at the use of the syntactically
ambiguous phrase as transition piece
between opposite moods, situations,
scenes:
"What's this all about?"
"What's it all about?"
"It's about this tall; and about this
wide; and about this country; about which
I'm singing about..."
See how they can shift, in five seconds,
from paranoid terror to patriotic mush.

Still a Regression
There's no doubt that side one of
"How Can..." is the most technically
mature of the Firesign Theatre's work
to date. There is enough music included to make it border on the pop-cantata. The use of studio-stereo effects
often pushes their syntax to either of
its two extremes -- sound or song.
If it is drama, it is non-transcribable
drama--a marked contrast to their first
record. They have learned a lot more
about -the medium with which they are
working. But I have said that it is also
a regression from "Electrician". It is.
"Electrician" started in the historical
past, brought us to the future, destroyed
the future, destroyed us (its audience),
and brought us back to the beginning
with a terrifying triple-dot closing."How
Can" limits its scope to the present,
and works through the relatively simple
(minded) device of sarcasm. The warped ideals of America are presented,
and we laugh, because we know that they

warped, and because we know that we
are superior to those who believe that
they are not warped.

John Q. Smith
To my mind, this is a back-slapping
egotistic sort of humor-- not worthy
of identification with an attempt at serious drama. And this is serious drama.
There is a very deft analogy being developed-- a motor journey to the heart
of America becomes a journey into the
mind of an American ("Mr. and Mrs.
'John Q. Smith; of Anytown, USA").
The materialism which keeps America,
literally, moving (symoblized by the
luxury car) is seen to be analogous to
psychedelic drugs-- both are external
and overpriced, both are capable of creating and transforming immediate environment (as opposed to general living
environment), both work primarily on
the psychology of America, and both are
equally useful or useless, depending on
point of view. Thus, despite certain
diversions, "How Can..." becomes a
rather drastic and startling statement
about the nature of life in America.
Side two-- "The Adventures of Nick
Danger, Third Eye"— is not as original
as side one, but it is never-the-less interesting. It is a paradoy radio-program, a take-off on Humphrey Bogart
and Peter Lorre's "The Maltese Falcon"; and is replete with art/life confusion-- actors losing their places in
the script or getting caught in each
other's flashbacks.
Despite certain shortcomings, "How
Can" and "Danger" are worth hearing.
If you're intrigued by the possibilities
of the form, as I am, by all means hear
"Electrician". And I think it's safe to
hold your breath waiting for the Firesign Theatre's third album. Like I say,
I trust them.

Reviewing Records, Eren If They Aren't
By ELLIOT KRIEGER
There's something about the Firesign
'Theatre that makes me want to trust
them. It's partly that their fi.rst record
("Waiting for the Electrician, or Someone Like Him") was so brilliant. It's
Partly that I feel that they're working
On a form of dramatic communication
both very old and very new--and maybe
very important.
The Firesign Theatre makes records,
but, formally, they are kissing cousins
with the radio drama-- a dramatic event
created in the studio rather than on the
stage. True, radio drama imposes some
drasitc (and obvious) limitations on the
'resources of tne drama. But radio drama has its own intrinsic advantages. For
one thing, the audience, participating with
only one sense, expects much less of a
dramatic illusion and is therefore more
willing to accept rapid leaps in time,
Space and sensibility -- a particularly
' appropriate advantage for a contemporary dramatic medium.
Another thing -- when made in a recording studio, radio drama can have
a near infinite number of characters,
events and effect; and a near minimum
of mistakes. Also, audial performance
before a private audience can create
some very intriguing psychologie situations—creation of paranoic reaction,
second person direct address, inclusion
of the audience in the sound pattern.
And then, considering the marketability
and accessibility of records, I'm surprised (and sorry) that radio drama
has not yet become a trend.

Unstageable
As to their first record-- if you haven't
heard it, you should have. I would call it
a syntactic and a vocal drama. It relies
heavily on homonym and malaprop and on

an astonishing diversity of accent and
inflection. "Electrician" could not be
staged, not even in the mind (as one
tends to "stage" written narratives such
as novels). I have often wondered whether it could be filmed, and have decided
that although it probably could, it should
not be.
Part of the brilliance of "Electrician" is its fluidity-- almost as soon
as one can identify locale, one is shuffled along, without transition, to a new
place. Any addition of visual imagery
would add either new clues or new confusion. Neither are needed-- the record's timing is perfect. "Electrician" is one of those very rare art works
in which the form is a totally appropriate extension of the content.
What worried me was the content. The
record was an apocalyptic work-- selfconsciously so. Now when a group's
first work is an apocalypse, what happens
next? I would say that they either regress, repeat, or become immortal. The
Firesign Theatre may have done all
three.

Uncanny Verbal Dexterity
Their second record is called "How
Can You Be in Two Places At Once,
When You're Not Anywhere At All"
(Columbia, CS-9884). The cover of the
record bears the slogan "All Hail Marx
and Lennon"— beneath pictures of Grouch° and John. This gives you an idea of
what to watch out for in "How Can..."-bad puns. Side one of this record contains a great deal of vaudeville-like humor; and to my mind, for a group with
the talents of the Firesign Theatre,
that's just fodder.

Yet, their verbal dexterity, their uncanny ability at the double-talk/doubletake and the non sequitor, so apparent

in "Electrician", seems to have reached new levels of pointed insanity in
"How Can...": the 'here' is told to go
to the People, "who wouldn't say no to
yesterday, or yes instead of knowing it
A sign on the highway reads
all!"
"Merging Buses Ahead." A motorist
shouts, "Get a hair-lip!" Also, the Firesign Theatre has even improved its
ability at the use of the syntactically
ambiguous phrase as transition piece
between opposite moods, situations,
scenes:
"What's this all about?"
"What's it all about?"
"It's about this tall; and about this
wide; and about this country; about which
I'm singing about..."
See how they can shift, in five seconds,
from paranoid terror to patriotic mush.

Still a Regression
There's no doubt that side one of
"How Can..." is the most technically
mature of the Firesign Theatre's work
to date. There is enough music included to make it border on the pop-cantata. The use of studio-stereo effects
often pushes their syntax to either of
its two extremes -- sound or song.
If it is drama, it is non-transcribable
drama--a marked contrast to their first
record. They have learned a lot more
about -the medium with which they are
working. But I have said that it is also
a regression from "Electrician". It is.
"Electrician" started in the historical
past, brought us to the future, destroyed
the future, destroyed us (its audience),
and brought us back to the beginning
with a terrifying triple-dot closing."How
Can" limits its scope to the present,
and works through the relatively simple
(minded) device of sarcasm. The warped ideals of America are presented,
and we laugh, because we know that they

warped, and because we know that we
are superior to those who believe that
they are not warped.

John Q. Smith
To my mind, this is a back-slapping
egotistic sort of humor-- not worthy
of identification with an attempt at serious drama. And this is serious drama.
There is a very deft analogy being developed-- a motor journey to the heart
of America becomes a journey into the
mind of an American ("Mr. and Mrs.
'John Q. Smith; of Anytown, USA").
The materialism which keeps America,
literally, moving (symoblized by the
luxury car) is seen to be analogous to
psychedelic drugs-- both are external
and overpriced, both are capable of creating and transforming immediate environment (as opposed to general living
environment), both work primarily on
the psychology of America, and both are
equally useful or useless, depending on
point of view. Thus, despite certain
diversions, "How Can..." becomes a
rather drastic and startling statement
about the nature of life in America.
Side two-- "The Adventures of Nick
Danger, Third Eye"— is not as original
as side one, but it is never-the-less interesting. It is a paradoy radio-program, a take-off on Humphrey Bogart
and Peter Lorre's "The Maltese Falcon"; and is replete with art/life confusion-- actors losing their places in
the script or getting caught in each
other's flashbacks.
Despite certain shortcomings, "How
Can" and "Danger" are worth hearing.
If you're intrigued by the possibilities
of the form, as I am, by all means hear
"Electrician". And I think it's safe to
hold your breath waiting for the Firesign Theatre's third album. Like I say,
I trust them.
